dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Ocean Cleanup just deployed their floating boom system from the Golden Gate Bridge this past Sunday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Ocean Cleanup just deployed their floating boom system from the Golden Gate Bridge this past Sunday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, that's the one started by Boyan Slat back in 2014, when he was only 19.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, that's the one started by Boyan Slat back in twenty fourteen, when he was only nineteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're aiming to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in just six years with these booms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're aiming to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in just six years with these booms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's… ambitious. Each boom is supposed to collect up to 140,000 pounds of plastic per year, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's... ambitious. Each boom is supposed to collect up to one hundred forty thousand pounds of plastic per year, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each boom will trap up to 150,000 pounds of plastic per year as they float along the currents between California and Hawaii.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they're gonna drift along currents between California and Hawaii, forming these U-shaped barriers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they're gonna drift along currents between California and Hawaii, forming these U-shaped barriers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom drifts along with the local currents, creating a U-shaped formation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: With netting hanging down about 10 feet to catch smaller bits of plastic—but hopefully not marine life.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With netting hanging down about ten feet to catch smaller bits of plastic-but hopefully not marine life.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the boom floats, it collects trash in the U shaped system, which has 10 feet of netting below it to collect smaller fragments of plastic. The idea is that the 10 feet of netting is not deep enough that fish can't swim below it, with the hope that the boom will collect trash and not fish.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's the idea, though it's still unproven out in the open ocean. But honestly, it's the closest thing we've got to a real solution at this scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the idea, though it's still unproven out in the open ocean. But honestly, it's the closest thing we've got to a real solution at this scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have. No other company has a deployable system able to clean up the garbage patch on this scale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the garbage patch itself is just massive—like, 1.7 million square kilometers. You can see it from space.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the garbage patch itself is just massive-like, one point seven million square kilometers. You can see it from space.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of terrifying when you think about it. But if this works, they could start towing these systems out around late October.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of terrifying when you think about it. But if this works, they could start towing these systems out around late October.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, after undergoing testing, will be towed out 1,400 miles to the garbage patch around mid-October and begin collecting trash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They've got some serious backing too—Peter Thiel and Marc Benioff are involved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They've got some serious backing too-Peter Thiel and Marc Benioff are involved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is backed by some heavy hitters in the tech industry, including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com Continued testing and deployment of additional boom systems will help further refine the systems to be more efficient and less disruptive to ocean ecosystems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, big names. And the organization's really banking on scaling this up with more booms over time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, big names. And the organization's really banking on scaling this up with more booms over time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Fingers crossed the testing goes well. It'd be huge if they can pull this off without harming ecosystems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fingers crossed the testing goes well. It'd be huge if they can pull this off without harming ecosystems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. We're long overdue for some good news on the ocean cleanup front.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. We're long overdue for some good news on the ocean cleanup front.
